title: 107_s2455
content: The "National Small Business Regulatory Assistance Act of 2002" establishes a pilot program to provide confidential assistance to small businesses, improve compliance with regulations, create partnerships among federal agencies, gather feedback on the regulatory environment, and utilize Small Business Development Centers for regulatory compliance programs. The Act establishes a Small Business Regulatory Assistance Pilot Program under the Small Business Act to provide confidential assistance to small businesses and improve regulatory compliance. The definitions in this section clarify terms like Administrator, Association, participating small business development center, pilot program, and regulatory compliance assistance. The Administrator will establish a pilot program to provide regulatory compliance assistance to small businesses through Small Business Development Centers, the Association, and Federal compliance partnership programs in various States and territories. The Administrator will establish a pilot program with Small Business Development Centers to provide regulatory compliance assistance to small businesses, including access to information, training, educational activities, and one-on-one counseling on Federal compliance. The Small Business Development Centers will offer regulatory compliance assistance to small businesses, including counseling, technical assistance, and referrals to experts. Each center must submit quarterly reports to the Administrator summarizing regulatory activities. The Small Business Development Centers will provide regulatory compliance assistance to small businesses and submit quarterly reports to the Administrator summarizing regulatory activities in electronic form. Interim reports with data or information can also be transmitted to the Administrator between quarterly reports. The Administrator may not require disclosure of small business names or addresses unless ordered by a court in enforcement actions. The Administrator will act as a data repository and clearinghouse for information submitted by Small Business Development Centers. The Administrator acts as a data repository for information from Small Business Development Centers, providing an annual report to the President and Congress on assistance provided and small businesses helped under the pilot program. The pilot program involves Small Business Development Centers providing assistance to business concerns, including outreach activities and cases of conflicting advice on compliance with regulations. The pilot program involves Small Business Development Centers providing assistance to small business concerns, including recommendations for improving regulations and identifying burdensome regulations for reduction or elimination. Eligibility for the program requires certification under section 21(k)(2). The pilot program involves Small Business Development Centers providing assistance to small business concerns, including recommendations for improving regulations and identifying burdensome regulations for reduction or elimination. The Administrator may waive certification requirements for centers making a good faith effort. The subsection will take effect on October 1, 2002. The Administrator will select two states from each group to participate in the pilot program. The pilot program established by this section involves Small Business Development Centers providing assistance to small business concerns in different groups of states. The Administrator will select two states from each group to participate in the program. The pilot program involves Small Business Development Centers assisting small businesses in various state groups. The Administrator will select two states from each group to participate within 60 days of promulgating regulations. Matching funds are not required for assistance under the program. Each selected state program will receive grants. Each State program selected for a grant under subsection (f) can receive an amount based on the state's population compared to all states with selected programs. The minimum grant amount is $200,000. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2003 and beyond to carry out the pilot program. The Administrator can only use these funds for the program. An evaluation will be conducted after 3 years, with recommendations on extending the program to all Small Business Development Centers. The pilot program can only be carried out with appropriated funds specifically for this purpose. SEC. 5. PROMULGATION OF REGULATIONS. After providing notice and an opportunity for comment, the Administrator will promulgate final regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The regulations will establish priorities for assistance, standards for services provided by Small Business Development Centers, national service delivery standards, work plan requirements, and educational and technical standards. The final regulations for the pilot program will include standards for the competency of experts and assistance providers referred to small businesses. SEC. 6. Privacy requirements for small business development centers. Section 21(c) of the Small Business Act is amended to include privacy requirements for Small Business Development Centers, prohibiting the disclosure of names or addresses of individuals or small businesses without consent, except in cases ordered by a court in enforcement actions. The Administrator shall issue regulations for requiring disclosures during financial audits of Small Business Development Centers.
